thread.title_full: Forget Senate inquiries, IOOF chairman Roger Sexton would rather grill lobster

author: CBD
title: Forget Senate inquiries, IOOF chairman Roger Sexton would rather grill lobster
text:
Illustration: John Shakespeare
It must be heartbreaking when a chairman has to divide his finite time between competing interests.
Take IOOF chairman Roger Sexton who was unable to accompany his chief executive, Chris Kelaher​ , to a Senate grilling last week while he put the finishing touches on the public float of his premium food shop, Beston Global Food Company.
There must have been a lot of work for the initial public offering, which aims to raise up to $130 million for Beston.
It plans to invest in well-established companies in the region to profit from Asia's "dining boom," according to the prospectus released on Tuesday.
Advertisement "Our goal is to be recognised as a reliable, high quality and consistent provider to burgeoning global consumer markets which are becoming increasingly concerned about issues of food safety," Sexton said.
You can imagine the exhaustive quality control our chairman would have to conduct on Beston's "export grade lobster" interests in Australasia, organic milk and fine cheese makers.
It will help avoid the sort of trouble that IOOF ran into.
Its shares have yet to recover after Fairfax Media published allegations of questionable behaviour by staff that the company failed to pass on to the authorities.
Lobster and organic cheese sounds much more palatable doesn't it?
Especially when Sexton has a 5.4 per cent stake in Beston, and more cream from Beston's investment manager, which he controls.
Sexton had been asked to attend the same hearing as Kelaher​ but it seems he may not miss out on the experience – it's tipped he will get to attend a separate hearing in the coming months to answer questions about his knowledge of IOOF's internal investigations into insider trading and front running.
Mean beans It takes a lot to rile up your average bean counter, it is what made them perfect fodder for Monty Python's classic Accountancy Shanty in The Meaning of Life .
So we were always going to have a revolt on our hands when a bunch of financial advisers were threatening to soil their patch.
It started with a story in a story in the Financial Observer reporting on a rebranding exercise by Jim Stackpool 's​ Strategic Consulting and Training (SCAT) - an advisory shop for financial advisers.
Stackpool​ came up with the bright idea of developing a "new designation" to identify professionals with the "right skills" to remove financial complexity for clients.
And the designation for the newly named Certainty Advice Group, is the Certainty adviser (CA) designation.
Not to be confused with the highly-credentialled bean counting professionals, the chartered accountants (CA), right?
"I am a CA. CA is hardest & most rigorous profes. exams I've ever done across Aust, Eng & US. These people are not CAs," tweeted the indi adviser from Quantum Financial, Tim Mackay CFP CA MBA BEc (Hons).
"We certainty don't want any confusion with the Chartered Accountant designation," Stackpool told CBD.
"We'll aim to be known as Certainty Advisers designate by our 'C' symbol rather than CA Advisers."
Stackpool indicated there is no reason to panic just yet, as the registration process is likely to take years - even if it is successful.
Turf war To give readers, and Stackpool, an understanding of the rough and tumble world of accounting professional bodies, we need only look at a court case which has just concluded on the other side of the ditch.
CPA Australia landed on Kiwi turf in 2012, ending the monopoly enjoyed by The New Zealand Institute of Chartered Accountants (NZICA).
War was declared, and the NZICA unleashed a marketing campaign against the CPA called "Project Ambush".
The NZICA published ads that year stating "in accounting there's best practice and then there's second-best practice". Oooh.
In 2013, its boss Kirsten Patterson , seriously 'dissed​ the CPAs at a conference saying the rival bean crew: "Wastes or misuses membership fees to pay for expensive television advertising".
As if that wasn't inflammatory enough, she then said CPA Australia is a "second-rate designation that has undermined the accounting profession in New Zealand."
CPA Australia now claims these local mean beans defamed it in speeches at industry events and breached the Fair Trading Act in statements in flyers and advertisements.
In the court case which ended Tuesday, CPA is seeking a declaration of defamation and $NZ50,000 for the Fair Trading Act breaches.
CPA Australia's legal counsel, Alan Galbraith QC told the court the rival body engaged in "professional denigration" that was "quite extraordinary and offensive".
Bruce Gray QC told the High Court in Wellington on Tuesday that his client, the NZICA, had made a "clumsy response" with its campaign and speeches by Patterson, but said they were not defamatory.
"Corporates have no personal reputation," Gray said at an earlier hearing. "They have no feelings to hurt."
May the best bean body win.
